Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?

Are there postnominal articles?

Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?

Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?

Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?

khwaci-nta
cookie-PL
'cookies among other things'

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
tharu-nta
Tharu-PL

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?

baga nnani=ja
1SG.POSS clothes=TOP
'my clothes'

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Comment: "Property-concept modification (e.g. ‘beautiful person’) is encoded by the adnominal clause construction with a stative verb predicate (e.g. ‘a person (who) is beautiful’). The stative verb must in this case be a participial form, like ordinary verbs in adnominal clauses."
Example:
khanu ttu=ka mabin abja-ta-ru ttu
DIST person=CMP more beautiful-PST-PTCP person
‘the person who was more beautiful than that person’

Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?

Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Example: nnu=ja Tharu=ŋa uta khi-ta-n=do. yesterday=TOP Taro=NOM song do-PST-IND=SFP ‘Taro sang a song yesterday.’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?

Example:
khica tharu=nki thuras-ja-n. just.now Tharu=DIR give-PERF-IND 
‘(I) just have given (it) to Tharu.’

Example: khari=ja dunan-ttu=du a-ru/*Ø. DIST=TOP Yonaguni-person=FOC COP-PTCP/*Ø ‘(S)he is a Yonaguni islander.’

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?

Detailed comment:
bun for animates
an for inanimates
Example:
inu=ŋa maasiku bu-n
dog=NOM lot be-IND
‘There are a lot of dogs.’ 
agami=ŋa maasiku bu-n
child=NOM lot exist-IND
‘There are lots of children.’

What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?

tharu=ŋa i maga-ta-n. Tharu=NOM rice cook-PST-IND

nai=gara i hu-n=do
now=ABL rice eat-IND=SFP

khanu ttu=ŋa santi tti-cu-n. DIST person=NOM sanshin play-MED-ABIL-IND

child=NOM water drink-PRES-IND

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Example:
[anu=du nn-anu khatarai khir-iba]=ndi umu-i
1SG=FOC look-NEG.PTCP pretention do-CIRC=QT think-MED
‘(The woman) thought, “(They) pretend not to see me, so. . .”, and. . .’

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Comment: negation is marked on the verb, which appears to be clause-final

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Example:
da=nki hi-nna
house=DIR go-PROH
‘Do not go home.’ 
mata nni ccaŋir-anu-nki=du bu-ru-na? again rice wash-NEG-SEQ=FOC IPF-PTCP-YNQ ‘Are (you) not washing the rice again?’

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Comment: "The existential verb an have a special sup- pletive negative form minun (25a), which is also used with stative verbs and to negate the perfect aspect […] The negation of the perfect is marked by the special negative form minun follow- ing the medial form of the verb, which constitutes further evidence that the perfect etymologically comes from the medial form of the verb followed by the existential verb an.”
Example:
khari=ja dunan-ttu=ja ar-anu-n/*Ø. DIST=TOP Yonaguni-person=TOP COP-NEG-IND/*Ø ‘(S)he is not a Yonaguni person.’ 
khumi=ja baga nnani=ja {minu-n, *ar-anu-n}. here.LOC=TOP 1.GEN clothes=TOP {exist.NEG-IND, *COP-NEG-IND} ‘My clothes are not here.’ 
khu=ja baga nnani=ja {*minu-n, ar-anu-n}. PROX=TOP 1.GEN clothes=TOP {*exist.NEG-IND, COP-NEG-IND} ‘These are not my clothes.’ 
madi Tharu=nki thuras-i minu-n. yet Taro=DIR give-MED IPF.NEG-IND ‘(I) have not given (it) to Taro yet.’

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?

Example:
khunu ujantu=ŋa maju=ni h-ari-ta-n. PROX mouse=NOM cat=LOC eat-PASS-PST-IND
‘This mouse was eaten by the cat.’

a=ŋa tharu=nki i mag-ami-ta-n
1SG=NOM Tharu=DIR rice cook-CAUS-PST-IND
‘I made Tharu cook rice.’

khanu ttu=ni din maasiku {*bu, a}-n=do. DIST person=LOC money many exist-IND=SFP ‘That person has a lot of money.’ (Literally ‘A lot of money exists in that person.’)

there.LOC exist-PTCP horse
